Drought-Proofing Strategies in Timor-Leste

Adapting to Climate Change through the National Adaptation Plan

Key Points on Drought in Timor-Leste:

  • Timor-Leste experiences a pronounced dry season from approximately June to November
  • Some areas receive little to no rainfall for 8 months of the year
  • Droughts are expected to become more frequent and severe due to climate change
  • El Ni√±o events cause overall drier conditions and reduced rainfall in the wet season
  • Droughts lead to decreased agricultural production, food insecurity, and water shortages

Enhancing Government and Community Strategies to Respond to Drought

  • Integrate drought response strategies across government agencies including environment, water resources, forestry and agriculture
  • Improve institutional and community capacity, especially of vulnerable groups like women and children, to prepare for and respond to drought
  • Incorporate climate risk information and drought response into traditional disaster risk reduction practices
  • Integrate water conservation and drought risk reduction approaches into Tara Bandu (customary laws)

Improving Water Resource Management

  • Build climate-resilient infrastructure to protect water resources, including enhancing water harvesting, storage, distribution and management systems
  • Implement integrated water resource management approaches to protect and rehabilitate critical watersheds
  • Control water usage by industry and implement water pollution control standards
  • Design water management systems that assess demand and sustainable supply under climate change scenarios
  • Promote water conservation and protection of springs and groundwater recharge areas

Climate-Smart Agriculture Practices

  • Implement sustainable land management practices that promote climate resilience such as permanent agriculture, reduced burning, reduced erosion and improved soil fertility
  • Identify and map climate-smart agricultural practices and conduct cost-benefit analyses
  • Research and promote drought-resistant, water-tolerant and fast-growing crop varieties
  • Integrate agro-forestry and watershed management approaches
  • Improve agricultural extension services to disseminate climate-smart techniques to farmers

Managing Ecosystems for Drought Resilience

  • Identify biodiversity and ecosystems at risk from climate change impacts including drought
  • Incorporate ecosystem management approaches into national planning for watershed management
  • Reforest degraded lands to reduce climate vulnerability of forests and provide sustainable fuel wood
  • Maintain and expand mangrove forests to protect coastal areas and resources
  • Promote community-based forest resource management

Next Steps

  • Develop implementation plans for priority drought-proofing actions
  • Conduct additional research on drought impacts and vulnerabilities
  • Improve drought monitoring and early warning systems
  • Mobilize financing to implement adaptation priorities
  • Strengthen capacities of government, communities and the private sector to manage drought risks
  • Monitor and evaluate effectiveness of implemented strategies and share lessons learned
